As the most popular syndicated show on TV, with tens of millions of viewers every day, competition to get on â€œWheel of Fortuneâ€ is fierce: Millions of people apply to get on the game show every year. Of those, according to the showâ€™s website , only 10,000 are selected to audition. Out of that pool, a mere 600 end up on the show, and of those, just 200 make it to the final round. Matt McMahan was one of them.
If getting on the show is hard, winning is harder still â€” requiring not just puzzle-solving acumen and the ability to think on oneâ€™s feet, but also strategy and luck. Making big bucks on the show is extremely difficult. McMahan won more than $30,000. That buys a lot of vowels.
While McMahan and his partner, Adam Hart, were regular â€œWheelâ€ viewers, he never gave serious thought to competing. One day, however, the two caught a â€œTeacherâ€™s Weekâ€ rerun â€” a themed episode where all the players are teachers. While McMahan worked as an actor for several years â€” including in the most recent revival of â€œLes MisÃ©rablesâ€ â€” he currently teaches second grade in the Bronx as part of Teach for America. When â€œWheelâ€ announced it was seeking contestants for another Teacherâ€™s Week, Hart urged him to apply.
â€œI knew he would get on if he tried,â€ Hart said. â€œHeâ€™s enthusiastic about teaching, he works in a low-income school, heâ€™s gorgeous, and heâ€™s been on Broadway. TV would love him.â€
Auditioning for the show Getting on is a multistep process, the first of which involves making an introductory video. McMahan filmed one on his phone, which Hart â€” another former musical theater actor â€” â€œstage mom-edâ€: â€œWe did multiple takes; I kept telling him to smile, to show more enthusiasm.â€
Matt McMahan CBS A month after he sent the video in, a representative from the show invited him to the next step: a tryout in Brooklyn, where applicants took turns playing a version of the game and were given 25 fill-in-the-blank word games, of which they had to solve 15 within a set time.
â€œThey want to know that you understand the puzzles, that you can speak clearly and loudly and follow directions, and that you wonâ€™t freak out,â€ McMahan said. The show did not return requests for comment.
While McMahan met his fill-in-the-blank quota, he was not, unlike other aspiring contestants, asked to stay for additional tests, leading him to believe he didnâ€™t make the cut. â€œBased on my acting experience, if youâ€™re not asked to stay after an audition and others are, you didnâ€™t get it,â€ he said.
Thinking his tryout would just be an amusing story, he eventually forgot about it until â€” appropriately â€” the final day of the school year, when he was contacted and told to pack his bags. The show tapes in Los Angeles, and gives out-of-town contestants $1,000 to use toward their flights and accommodations.
The show, which has aired more than 6,000 episodes since 1975, shoots as many as six episodes a day on the days it films, meaning thereâ€™s a lag between when one is filmed and when it airs. McMahanâ€™s was taped on July 14 and aired Sept. 12 as the showâ€™s 34th season premiere; other contestants can wait as long as six months to see their episode.
On the day of his taping, McMahan and his fellow competitors were shuttled to the studio to await their turn in the spotlight. To kill time, he did more practice puzzles.
And then it was time to meet host Pat Sajak â€” â€œvery niceâ€ â€” hostess Vanna White â€” â€œoh Vanna, so lovelyâ€ â€” and to spin the â€œvery very heavyâ€ wheel. In the audience was his mother, Misty McMahan, who flew in from Denver, and his grandmother, Virginia â€œGingerâ€ Brown, visiting from Dallas.

Because his schoolâ€™s summer vacation coincided with him learning he would be on the show, McMahan was able to dedicate himself full-time to preparation. His practice involved playing the â€œWheel of Fortuneâ€ app and Whatâ€™s the Saying â€” a word game where players decode idioms â€” and working his way through hangman puzzles created by his mother and Hart. And of course he watched the show, teaching himself to recognize patterns â€” for example, where consonants might repeat. â€œI wasnâ€™t guessing to figure out the puzzle, I was guessing for multiples of letters,â€ he said. â€œThe more letters you have, the easier to solve.â€
While â€œWheelâ€ is a puzzle game, thereâ€™s also an element of strategy that the â€œmore lettersâ€ tactic plays into, as the player with the highest score at the end of the competition is the one who moves on to the final round. â€œIf the round is just about money, then you want to make as much as you can,â€ McMahan explained. â€œThe rounds with prizes, on the other hand, you want to solve as quickly as possible. Once you get one, you donâ€™t want to risk landing on bankruptcy.â€
Even the best solver can be destroyed by a bad spin of the wheel, but McMahan proved lucky on this score. After making what he described as a rookie mistake â€” asking for a letter that had previously been called, which meant he forfeited his turn (despite a board displaying which letters have been selected, not visible to TV audiences) â€” he regained control of the wheel within a minute: One contestant spun and landed on â€œBankrupt,â€ the next on â€œLose a Turn.â€ He landed on lucrative spots, which led to outsize payouts for common letters, at one point earning $4,000 for guessing T in the puzzle â€œHEARTWARMING HANDWRITTEN LETTER.â€ By the end, he was more than $30,000 ahead of his nearest competitor (the third was stuck at $0).
His dominance was so total that he confessed feeling bad about it to a competitor. â€œDonâ€™t,â€ he recalled her responding. â€œTake them for all theyâ€™re worth.â€

What he took them for, in the end, was $31,700 in cash and prizes â€” $16,400 in cash and two vacations valued at $15,300: a trip to Chile and a cruise down the Danube River. All game show winnings â€” cash, prizes, trips, etc. â€” are taxed like regular income. The show allowed him to find less expensive versions of his two trips, so he was able to pay taxes on vacations worth $10,800 instead of the original $15,300. In the end, he estimates heâ€™ll only walk away with about $6,000 in cash.
That game show prizes come with strings attached may come as a surprise to contestants who expect their winnings free and clear, but McMahan said he and Hart never debated forgoing the vacations, especially since his cash winnings would cover the taxes they owed on them. â€œWe would have loved the extra $2,000, but given that itâ€™s just the two of us and we share living expenses, experiences are worth more than money right now,â€ he said.
Still, the success has them recommending â€œWheelâ€ as an unconventional income opportunity to friends, and even considering the rest of the game show landscape.
â€œGinger,â€ Hart said, referring to McMahanâ€™s grandmother, â€œkeeps texting me about getting on â€˜The $100,000 Pyramid.â€™â€
